classifications.note: Thin lens equation: $\frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{d_o} + \frac{1}{d_i}$; Mirror equation: $\frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{d_o} + \frac{1}{d_i}$; Magnification: $M = -\frac{d_i}{d_o}$; Optical power: $P = \frac{1}{f}$ (in diopters, f in meters)

principles.statement: Optical systems follow precise mathematical relationships with specific sign conventions: Thin Lens Equation: $\frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{d_o} + \frac{1}{d_i}$; Derived from similar triangles and Snell's Law; Applies to both converging and diverging lenses. Mirror Equation: $\frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{d_o} + \frac{1}{d_i}$; Identical mathematical form to lens equation; Different sign convention interpretation. Magnification Formula: $M = \frac{h_i}{h_o} = -\frac{d_i}{d_o}$; |M| > 1: magnified; |M| < 1: diminished; M > 0: upright; M < 0: inverted. Real-is-Positive Convention: Object distance (d_o): always positive; Image distance (d_i): positive for real images, negative for virtual images; Focal length (f): positive for converging lenses/concave mirrors, negative for diverging lenses/convex mirrors; Magnification (M): negative for inverted images, positive for upright images. Cartesian Sign Convention: Light travels left to right; Distances measured from optical element; Right: positive, Left: negative; Above axis: positive, Below: negative; Converging: positive f, Diverging: negative f. Optical Power: $P = \frac{1}{f}$ (f in meters); Unit: diopter (D); Converging: positive power; Diverging: negative power; Multiple elements: $P_{total} = P_1 + P_2 + \cdots$. Derivation Basis: Similar triangles in ray diagrams; Paraxial approximation (small angles); Gaussian optics formulation.
principles.application: Apply thin lens equation to various lens types. Use mirror equation for different mirrors. Calculate magnification and image characteristics. Convert between different sign conventions. Solve optical power problems. Derive optical relationships from first principles.
principles.example: Calculate image position using given parameters. Determine magnification for optical system. Convert focal length to optical power. Solve for unknown parameter in optical equation.
principles.analogy: Like a precise GPS navigation system - the equations provide exact mathematical coordinates (image position and characteristics) for optical elements, while sign conventions ensure everyone uses the same map orientation and direction definitions

worked_examples.title: Basic Thin Lens Equation Application
worked_examples.problem: A converging lens has focal length 15 cm. An object is placed 30 cm from the lens. Calculate the image position, magnification, and describe the image characteristics.

step_by_step.explanation: Real image (d_i > 0), inverted (M < 0), same size (|M| = 1), located 30 cm from lens
Object at 2F (30 cm = 2×15 cm) produces image at 2F with unity magnification

worked_examples.final_answer: Image: 30 cm from lens, M = -1, real, inverted, same size; Demonstrates special case of object at 2F

worked_examples.title: Sign Convention Practice
worked_examples.problem: A diverging lens has focal length -20 cm. An object is placed 40 cm from the lens. Calculate the image position and magnification using the real-is-positive convention.

step_by_step.explanation: Diverging lens always produces virtual, upright, diminished images

worked_examples.final_answer: Image: 13.33 cm from lens (virtual), M = +0.333, upright, diminished; Confirms diverging lens characteristics

classifications.note: System magnification: $M_{total} = M_1 \times M_2 \times M_3 \cdots$; Effective focal length: $\frac{1}{f_{eff}} = \frac{1}{f_1} + \frac{1}{f_2} - \frac{d}{f_1 f_2}$; Tube length: distance between specific elements; Applications: scientific instruments, imaging systems, vision correction

principles.statement: Advanced optical applications require extended mathematical techniques: Multiple Element Systems: Analyze sequentially; Image from first element becomes object for second; Overall magnification: $M_{total} = M_1 \times M_2 \times M_3 \cdots$. Effective Focal Length: Two thin lenses separated by distance d: $\frac{1}{f_{eff}} = \frac{1}{f_1} + \frac{1}{f_2} - \frac{d}{f_1 f_2}$; Lenses in contact (d=0): $\frac{1}{f_{eff}} = \frac{1}{f_1} + \frac{1}{f_2}$. Unknown Parameter Solving: Use given information with optical equations; Often requires solving simultaneous equations; Common scenarios: find focal length given object and image positions; find object position for desired image characteristics. Telescope Systems: Astronomical telescope: $M = -\frac{f_{objective}}{f_{eyepiece}}$; Terrestrial telescope: includes erecting lens; Tube length: $L \approx f_{obj} + f_{eye}$. Microscope Systems: Compound microscope: $M_{total} = M_{obj} \times M_{eye}$; Objective: $M_{obj} = -\frac{L}{f_{obj}}$; Eyepiece: $M_{eye} = \frac{25}{f_{eye}}$ cm (normal eye); Tube length L typically 16-20 cm. Camera Systems: Lens equation determines focus; Depth of field calculations; f-number: $f/\#$ = $\frac{f}{D}$ (aperture diameter). Optical Design: Balancing multiple parameters; Correcting aberrations; Meeting specific performance requirements; Optimization techniques.

worked_examples.title: Two-Lens System Analysis
worked_examples.problem: Two converging lenses with f₁ = 10 cm and f₂ = 15 cm are separated by 35 cm. An object is placed 20 cm in front of the first lens. Calculate the final image position and overall magnification.

step_by_step.explanation: Distance between lenses = 35 cm, first image at 20 cm from first lens, so $d_{o2} = 35 - 20 = 15$ cm
Final image at infinity, system acts as beam expander/collimator

worked_examples.final_answer: Final image at infinity, M₁ = -1, M₂ → -∞; System produces collimated output from finite object

worked_examples.title: Microscope Design Calculation
worked_examples.problem: Design a compound microscope with total magnification 200× using an objective with focal length 0.8 cm and eyepiece with focal length 2.5 cm. Calculate the required tube length and verify the design.

step_by_step.explanation: Tube length = 16 cm, f_obj = 0.8 cm, f_eye = 2.5 cm gives M_total = 200×

worked_examples.final_answer: Required tube length = 16 cm; Design: f_obj = 0.8 cm, f_eye = 2.5 cm, L = 16 cm gives M_total = 200×

principles.statement: Real-world optical engineering applies fundamental equations to practical design problems: Vision Correction: Myopia (nearsightedness): diverging lens, $P = \frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{-FP}$ where FP is far point; Hyperopia (farsightedness): converging lens, $P = \frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{NP} - \frac{1}{25}$ cm where NP is near point; Astigmatism: cylindrical lens correction. Camera Systems: Lens equation: $\frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{s} + \frac{1}{s'}$; Focusing: moving lens relative to sensor; f-number: $N = \frac{f}{D}$ affecting depth of field and exposure; Zoom lenses: variable effective focal length. Projector Systems: Throw ratio: $R = \frac{D}{W}$ (distance to screen width); Keystone correction; Light efficiency calculations; Resolution requirements. Microscope Engineering: Numerical aperture: $NA = n\sin\theta$ determining resolution; Working distance constraints; illumination system design; Camera attachment compatibility. Telescope Design: Aperture size determining light gathering; Resolution: $\theta = 1.22\frac{\lambda}{D}$; Mounting and stability considerations; Camera and instrument interfaces. Optical System Optimization: Balancing multiple parameters: cost, size, weight, performance; Correcting aberrations: spherical, chromatic, coma; Meeting specific application requirements; Tolerance analysis and manufacturing constraints.

worked_examples.title: Vision Correction Prescription
worked_examples.problem: A nearsighted person has a far point of 2 meters (can see clearly only up to 2 m). Calculate the lens power needed to correct their vision to see distant objects clearly.

step_by_step.explanation: Lens should make distant objects (d_o = ∞) appear at person's far point (2 m)
For clear vision, virtual image should be at far point: d_i = -2 m (virtual image)
-0.50 D diverging lens corrects this mild myopia

worked_examples.final_answer: Required prescription: -0.50 diopters; Diverging lens with focal length -2 meters

worked_examples.problem: A camera with a 50 mm focal length lens is used to photograph an object 2 meters away. Calculate the image distance and magnification. If the sensor is 36 mm wide, what field of view is captured?

step_by_step.explanation: Camera captures 1.4 m wide area at 2 m distance with 38.7° field of view

worked_examples.final_answer: Image distance = 51.28 mm, M = -0.02564, Field of view = 38.7°; Demonstrates typical camera parameters

summary: The thin lens equation ($\frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{d_o} + \frac{1}{d_i}$) and mirror equation (identical mathematical form) provide the fundamental mathematical framework for analyzing optical systems. Combined with the magnification formula ($M = -\frac{d_i}{d_o}$) and proper sign conventions (Real-is-Positive: real images positive, virtual images negative; converging elements positive f, diverging elements negative f), these equations enable precise calculation of image characteristics without graphical construction. Optical power ($P = \frac{1}{f}$ in diopters) quantifies lens strength for vision correction applications. Multiple element systems are analyzed sequentially, with overall magnification as the product of individual magnifications. Real-world applications span vision correction (myopia: diverging lenses, hyperopia: converging lenses), camera design (focusing, field of view), projector systems (throw ratios), and scientific instruments (microscopes, telescopes). Advanced applications include solving for unknown parameters, optimizing system performance, and balancing engineering trade-offs in practical optical design. Mastery of these mathematical tools is essential for optical engineering across healthcare, photography, scientific research, and technology development.
